TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   Agitated and SOB: Gave 2mg IV morphine and ipratropium nebs.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - [**2129-3-5**] 11:00 PM
   Infusions:
   Furosemide (Lasix) - 10 mg/hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2129-3-6**] 12:49 AM
   Heparin Sodium - [**2129-3-6**] 01:00 AM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Flowsheet Data as of  [**2129-3-6**] 06:57 AM
   Vital signs
   Hemodynamic monitoring
   Fluid balance
                                                                  24 hours
                                                               Since 12 AM
   Tmax: 36.1
C (97
   Tcurrent: 36
C (96.8
   HR: 92 (88 - 108) bpm
   BP: 113/45(62) {98/43(57) - 134/75(79)} mmHg
   RR: 24 (16 - 26) insp/min
   SpO2: 96%
   Heart rhythm: SR (Sinus Rhythm)
             Total In:
                                                                    100 mL
                                                                     60 mL
   PO:
             TF:
   IVF:
                                                                    100 mL
                                                                     60 mL
   Blood products:
   Total out:
                                                                    400 mL
                                                                    970 mL
   Urine:
                                                                    400 mL
                                                                    970 mL
   NG:
   Stool:
   Drains:
   Balance:
                                                                   -300 mL
                                                                   -911 mL
   Respiratory support
   O2 Delivery Device: Nasal cannula
   SpO2: 96%
   ABG: ////
   Physical Examination
   GEN: Drowsy, oriented to hospital, year "19..." (best response).
   HEENT: NCAT, PERRL, no icterus, MM dry.
   NECK: Supple, JVP 15-20cm
   CV: Irregular rate and rhythm, nl S1 and S2, no m/r/g
   LUNGS: Decreased BS B/L, bibasilar crackles, expiratory wheezes b/l
   ABD: NABS. Soft, distended, NT.
   EXT: 3+ pitting edema b/l with erythema of BLE (L >R). Left 1st toe
   with dark hematoma & gangrenous skin with blister on dorsum of toe.
   Open wound at distal tip is dry and without drainage. Multiple toe
   amputations.
   PULSES: 1+ DP pulses bilat, PT pulses dopplerable.
   Labs / Radiology
        [image002.jpg]
   Assessment and Plan
   A&P: 82 yo male with a hx of CAD s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD
   presents with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection
   of wound in distal forefoot.
   .
   # Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%: Patient has significant
   volume overload on exam and has a positive heart failure ROS. BNP
   elevated to 8569. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies include
   Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular dysfunction.
   Had similar episode in [**12-6**], which responded well to IV diuresis.
   - Will bolus pt with 120mg IV furosemide and start gtt at 10mg/hr. Goal
   negative 2-3L over next 24 hrs, as tolerated by BP.
   - Cont PO metolazone.
   - TTE to assess for possible precipitants such as changes in valve
   function, new WMA.
   - Cont lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would
   avoid stopping B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   .
   # LLE ulcers and celllulitis: Plain films concerning for osteomyelitis.
   Given Vanco and Unasyn in ED. Vascular consulted and will consider
   debridement. Patient without leukocytosis or fever. Per vascular
   surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of his left LE.
   - Follow up vascular recs. [**Month (only) 60**] need foot MRI for further eval for
   osteomyelitis.
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   # Pulmonary opacity: Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA.
   Patient with nonproductive cough, but no fevers or leukocytosis. This
   will be well covered with his current abx regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .
   # CAD: S/p CABG [**10-5**]. Trop-T currently .23 -> .21 (baseline troponin
   .16-.23). MB negative. These labs make acute ischemia unlikely.
   Furthermore, no new ischemic changes noted on EKG.
   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol
   - 3rd set biomarkers in am
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   .
   # COPD: Good O2 sats, mild wheezes on exam.
   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
   # CKD: Creatinine 1.4 (baseline 1.5-2.5).
   - Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - Cont rosuvastatin
   .
   # DMII: Last HbA1C 5.8 ([**12-5**]).
   - Continue glargine and humalog ISS.
   .
   # Anemia: Hct 26, with baseline mid 20s.
   - Continue erythopoeitin
   - Check hct in am
   .
   # FEN:
   - Cardiac diabetic diet
   .
   # ACCESS: PIV
   .
   # PROPH: heparin SC, bowel reg
   .
   # DISPO: CCU pending diuresis with hemodynamic stability.
   .
   # Communication: Wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8347**]
   .
   # CODE: DNR/DNI per patient's wife
   ICU [**Name (NI) **]
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2129-3-5**] 10:27 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic heart failure (HF), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He presented with acute decompensated HF, left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%, and volume overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of heart failure: The patient's heart failure is already severe, and further decompensation could lead to cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, or even death.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's LLE ulcers and cellulitis may progress to osteomyelitis, which could lead to sepsis, limb loss, or even death.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pulmonary opacity on CXR is concerning for pneumonia, which could lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, or even death.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is currently well-controlled, but it could worsen, leading to heart failure, stroke, or even death.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is 1.4, which is concerning for acute kidney injury, especially given his history of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
6. Sepsis: The patient's infection and potential sepsis could lead to multi-organ failure, including cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal failure.
7. Poor wound healing: The patient's wound in the distal forefoot may not heal properly, leading to further complications, including infection, limb loss, or even death.
8. Catheter-related bloodstream infection: The patient has multiple IV lines and catheters, which could lead to catheter-related bloodstream infection, sepsis, or even death.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, close monitoring and aggressive management of his symptoms are necessary to prevent potential complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) following coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic heart failure (HF), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute decompensated HF, left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.1°C (97°F)
* Heart rate: 92 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 113/45 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Drowsy with slow answers, oriented to self, trouble finding a comfortable position
* Irregular rate and rhythm, normal S1 and S2, no murmurs or gallops
* Decreased breath sounds bilaterally, bibasilar crackles, expiratory wheezes bilaterally
* 3+ pitting edema bilaterally with erythema of the left lower extremity (LLE), left 1st toe with dark hematoma and gangrenous skin with blister on the dorsum of the toe
* Open wound at the distal tip is dry and without drainage

The patient's laboratory results and radiology reports are as follows:

* B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level: 8569
* Troponin level: 0.23 ng/mL (baseline 0.16-0.23 ng/mL)
* Creatinine level: 1.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.5-2.5 mg/dL)
* Hemoglobin A1C level: 5.8% (last measured 12-5)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Bolus administration of 120 mg IV furosemide and initiation of a 10 mg/hour infusion to achieve a negative fluid balance of 2-3 liters over the next 24 hours
* Continuation of oral metolazone
* TTE to assess for possible precipitants such as changes in valve function or new WMA
* Continuation of lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of blood pressure
* Consideration of debridement for the LLE ulcers and cellulitis
* Follow-up with vascular surgery for further evaluation of osteomyelitis
* Continuation of empiric vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam
* Wet-to-dry dressing on the toe and adaptation on bullae
* Monitoring of temperature, white blood cell count, and blood cultures

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of heart failure
* Development of acute kidney injury
* Progression of osteomyelitis
* Pneumonia
* Deep vein thrombosis
* Stress ulcer bleeding
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Hyperglycemia
* Hypoglycemia
* Anemia
* Hypertension
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Diabetic ketoacidosis

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve the patient's outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour ICU admission with a chief complaint of agitated and shortness of breath (SOB). They received 2mg IV morphine and ipratropium nebs for symptom management. The patient has a history of heart failure (CHF), systolic and diastolic, acute on chronic decubitus ulcer, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia. Vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C (97°F), heart rate of 92 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/45 mmHg. The patient is receiving various medications, including furosemide, heparin sodium, and piperacillin/tazobactam.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Complications: The patient's SOB and agitated state may indicate underlying respiratory compromise. Pneumonia, respiratory failure, or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) may develop if not properly managed.
2. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of CHF and PVD increases the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
3. Infection Complications: The patient's decubitus ulcer and PVD may increase the risk of infection, particularly if not properly managed. Sepsis, wound infection, or osteomyelitis may develop if not addressed promptly.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of CHF and PVD may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or bleeding.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's agitated state may indicate underlying neurological compromise. Seizures, stroke, or encephalopathy may develop if not properly managed.
6. Hemodynamic Complications: The patient's fluid balance and blood pressure may indicate underlying hemodynamic instability. Hypovolemic shock, cardiogenic shock, or septic shock may develop if not properly managed.
7. Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) Complications: The patient's PVD and immobility increase the risk of VTE. Pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis may develop if not properly managed.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify potential complications early and initiate prompt interventions to prevent adverse outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   A&P: 82 yo male with a hx of CAD s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD
   presents with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection
   of wound in distal forefoot.
   .
   # Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%: Patient has significant
   volume overload on exam and has a positive heart failure ROS. BNP
   elevated to 8569. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies include
   Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular dysfunction.
   Had similar episode in [**12-6**], which responded well to IV diuresis.
   Although has had difficulty with diuresis in past requiring CVVH and
   milrinone.
   - Continue with IV lasix boluses and lasix gtt.  Goal negative 2-3L
   daily, as tolerated by BP.
   - Cont PO metolazone.
   - Check [**Hospital1 **] lytes while aggressively diuresing
   - TTE to assess for possible precipitants such as changes in valve
   function, new WMA.
   - Cont lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would
   avoid stopping B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   .
   # LLE ulcers and celllulitis: Plain films concerning for osteomyelitis.
   Given Vanco and Unasyn in ED. Vascular consulted and will consider
   debridement. Patient without leukocytosis or fever. Per vascular
   surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of his left LE.
   - Follow up vascular recs. [**Month (only) 60**] need foot MRI for further eval for
   osteomyelitis.
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   # Pulmonary opacity: Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA.
   Patient with nonproductive cough, but no fevers or leukocytosis. This
   will be well covered with his current abx regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .
   # CAD: S/p CABG [**10-5**]. Trop-T currently .23 -> .21 (baseline troponin
   .16-.23). MB negative. These labs make acute ischemia unlikely.
   Furthermore, no new ischemic changes noted on EKG.
   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   .
   # COPD: Good O2 sats, mild wheezes on exam.
   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
   # CKD: Creatinine 1.4 (baseline 1.5-2.5).
   - Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - Cont rosuvastatin
   .
   # DMII: Last HbA1C 5.8 ([**12-5**]).
   - Continue glargine and humalog ISS.  Titrate up as tolerated.
   .
   # Anemia: Hct 26, with baseline mid 20s.
   - Continue erythopoeitin
   - Daily hcts
   .
   # FEN:
   - Cardiac diabetic diet
   .
   # ACCESS: PIV
   .
   # PROPH: heparin SC, bowel reg
   .
   # DISPO: CCU pending diuresis with hemodynamic stability.
   .
   # Communication: Wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8347**]
   .
   # CODE: DNR/DNI per patient's wife

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He presents with acute decompensated heart failure, left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, blood pressure of 113/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His physical examination reveals irregular heart rhythm, decreased bilateral breath sounds, and 3+ pitting edema bilaterally with erythema of the left lower extremity.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

1. Acute on chronic systolic heart failure: The patient's ejection fraction is 20-30%, and he has significant volume overload on examination. He has a positive heart failure review of systems and an elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level of 8569.
2. LLE ulcers and cellulitis: The patient has plain films concerning for osteomyelitis, and he is receiving empiric vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. He has poor options for revascularization of his left lower extremity.
3. Pulmonary opacity: The patient has a retrocardiac opacity on chest X-ray concerning for pneumonia, but he does not have fever or leukocytosis. His current antibiotic regimen should cover this condition.
4. CAD: The patient has had a CABG procedure and has a negative troponin level, making acute ischemia unlikely.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's heart rhythm is currently well-controlled, but he is not on warfarin anticoagulation.
6. CKD: The patient's creatinine level is 1.4, which is within the normal range for his baseline values.
7. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient is receiving rosuvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.
8. DMII: The patient's last hemoglobin A1C level was 5.8, and he is receiving glargine and humalog insulin.
9. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 26, which is within the normal range for his baseline values.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continuing IV lasix boluses and oral lasix to achieve a goal of negative 2-3 liters daily.
2. Monitoring the patient's blood pressure and electrolyte levels.
3. Performing a transesophageal echocardiogram to assess for possible precipitants of heart failure.
4. Continuing empiric antibiotics for LLE cellulitis and osteomyelitis.
5. Following up with vascular surgery for further evaluation and treatment of the patient's left lower extremity.
6. Monitoring the patient's blood cultures and sputum culture.
7. Continuing carvedilol and aspirin for CAD.
8. Continuing fluticasone-salmeterol for COPD.
9. Trending the patient's creatinine level and monitoring urine output.
10. Continuing rosuvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.
11. Continuing glargine and humalog insulin for DMII.
12. Continuing erythropoietin for anemia.

   Assessment and Plan
   A&P: 82 yo male with a hx of CAD s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD
   presents with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection
   of wound in distal forefoot.
   .
   # Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%: Patient has significant
   volume overload on exam and has a positive heart failure ROS. BNP
   elevated to 8569. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies include
   Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular dysfunction.
   Had similar episode in [**12-6**], which responded well to IV diuresis.
   - Will bolus pt with 120mg IV furosemide and start gtt at 10mg/hr. Goal
   negative 2-3L over next 24 hrs, as tolerated by BP.
   - Cont PO metolazone.
   - TTE to assess for possible precipitants such as changes in valve
   function, new WMA.
   - Cont lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would
   avoid stopping B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   .
   # LLE ulcers and celllulitis: Plain films concerning for osteomyelitis.
   Given Vanco and Unasyn in ED. Vascular consulted and will consider
   debridement. Patient without leukocytosis or fever. Per vascular
   surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of his left LE.
   - Follow up vascular recs. [**Month (only) 60**] need foot MRI for further eval for
   osteomyelitis.
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   # Pulmonary opacity: Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA.
   Patient with nonproductive cough, but no fevers or leukocytosis. This
   will be well covered with his current abx regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .
   # CAD: S/p CABG [**10-5**]. Trop-T currently .23 -> .21 (baseline troponin
   .16-.23). MB negative. These labs make acute ischemia unlikely.
   Furthermore, no new ischemic changes noted on EKG.
   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol
   - 3rd set biomarkers in am
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   .
   # COPD: Good O2 sats, mild wheezes on exam.
   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
   # CKD: Creatinine 1.4 (baseline 1.5-2.5).
   - Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - Cont rosuvastatin
   .
   # DMII: Last HbA1C 5.8 ([**12-5**]).
   - Continue glargine and humalog ISS.
   .
   # Anemia: Hct 26, with baseline mid 20s.
   - Continue erythopoeitin
   - Check hct in am
   .
   # FEN:
   - Cardiac diabetic diet
   .
   # ACCESS: PIV
   .
   # PROPH: heparin SC, bowel reg
   .
   # DISPO: CCU pending diuresis with hemodynamic stability.
   .
   # Communication: Wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8347**]
   .
   # CODE: DNR/DNI per patient's wife
   ICU [**Name (NI) **]

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD, who presents with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Acute on chronic systolic HF with EF 20-30%: The patient has significant volume overload on exam and has a positive heart failure ROS. BNP is elevated to 8569. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies include Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular dysfunction.
2. LLE ulcers and cellulitis: Plain films are concerning for osteomyelitis. The patient has been given Vanco and Unasyn in the ED, and vascular consultation has been obtained. Debridement is being considered, and the patient has poor options for revascularization of his left LE.
3. Pulmonary opacity: Retrocardiac opacity on CXR is concerning for PNA. The patient has a nonproductive cough, but no fevers or leukocytosis. This will be well covered with his current abx regimen.
4. CAD: The patient has a history of CABG and has had a recent increase in troponin levels, but these labs make acute ischemia unlikely. No new ischemic changes have been noted on EKG.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's rate is currently well controlled, and he is not on warfarin anticoagulation.
6. CKD: The patient's creatinine level is 1.4, which is within the normal range.
7. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient is being continued on rosuvastatin.
8. DMII: The patient's last HbA1C was 5.8, and he is being continued on glargine and humalog ISS.
9. Anemia: The patient's Hct is 26, and he is being continued on erythropoietin.

The patient is being managed with the following medications:

1. Furosemide (Lasix) 10mg/hour
2. Heparin Sodium
3. Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
4. Vancomycin (Vanco)
5. Unasyn
6. Metolazone
7. Lisinopril
8. Carvedilol
9. Fluticasone-salmeterol
10. Rosuvastatin
11. Glargine
12. Humalog ISS
13. Erythropoietin

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and his disposition is CCU pending diuresis with hemodynamic stability.

   of wound in distal forefoot.

   # Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%: Patient has significant

   elevated to 8569. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies include
   Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular dysfunction.
   Had similar episode in [**12-6**], which responded well to IV diuresis.
   Although has had difficulty with diuresis in past requiring CVVH and
   milrinone.
   - Continue with IV lasix boluses and lasix gtt.  Goal negative 2-3L
   daily, as tolerated by BP.

   - Check [**Hospital1 **] lytes while aggressively diuresing
   - TTE to assess for possible precipitants such as changes in valve
   function, new WMA.
   - Cont lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would
   avoid stopping B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   .
   # LLE ulcers and celllulitis: Plain films concerning for osteomyelitis.
   Given Vanco and Unasyn in ED. Vascular consulted and will consider
   debridement. Patient without leukocytosis or fever. Per vascular
   surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of his left LE.
   - Follow up vascular recs. [**Month (only) 60**] need foot MRI for further eval for
   osteomyelitis.
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CAD, systolic HF, and PVD who presents with acute decompensated HF, LLE cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. He has a positive heart failure ROS, and his BNP is elevated to 8569. He is being treated with IV diuresis, lasix, and metolazone, and his goal is to achieve a negative fluid balance of 2-3L daily.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Heart Failure: The patient's heart failure is acute on chronic, and his EF is 20-30%. He has significant volume overload, and his BNP is elevated. There is a risk of worsening heart failure if his fluid overload is not managed effectively.
2. Infection: The patient has LLE cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot, which may lead to sepsis and organ failure if not properly managed.
3. Respiratory Complications: The patient has mild wheezes on exam and is on oxygen therapy. There is a risk of respiratory failure if his respiratory status worsens.
4. Renal Complications: The patient has CKD, and his creatinine is 1.4. There is a risk of worsening renal function if his fluid overload is not managed effectively.
5. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has CAD and is at risk of developing acute ischemia. He is also at risk of developing arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient has anemia and is at risk of developing neurological complications, including seizures and stroke.
7. Infection-Related Complications: The patient has a positive blood culture, and there is a risk of developing infection-related complications, including sepsis and organ failure.

Overall, the patient is critically ill due to his acute on chronic heart failure, renal failure, and right heart failure. He requires close monitoring and management of his fluid overload, infection, and other medical complications to prevent worsening of his condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a chief complaint of vascular wound recs-Vanc/Zosyn. They have a history of heart failure (CHF), systolic and diastolic, acute on chronic peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia, delirium/confusion, and diabetes mellitus (DM), type I. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and diuretics. Their vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 94/33 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy through a nasal cannula and have a SpO2 of 98%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a positive fluid balance, with a total input of 1,357 mL and an output of 2,835 mL. Their laboratory results show mild anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and normal electrolyte levels. The patient's physical examination is limited due to their condition, with no assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of heart failure: The patient's history of CHF and acute on chronic PVD with critical limb ischemia increases their risk of worsening heart failure, which could lead to further fluid accumulation and respiratory distress.
2. Sepsis: The patient's infection and antibiotics may increase their risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's PVD and immobilization increase their risk of developing DVT, which could lead to pulmonary embolism and increased mortality.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's positive fluid balance and possible heart failure could lead to respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's DM and glycemic control measures may increase their risk of developing hyperglycemia, which could lead to increased mortality and morbidity.
6. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of catheters and lines increase their risk of developing infections, which could lead to sepsis and increased mortality.

   A&P: 82 yo male with a hx of CAD s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD
   presents with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection
   of wound in distal forefoot.
   .
   1. Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%: Patient continues to be
   overloaded and has been diuresing well on lasix drip with metolazone.
   Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies include Na intake,
   hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular dysfunction. Had similar
   episode in [**12-6**], which responded well to IV diuresis.
   - Continue lasix gtt with PO metolazone.  Goal negative 3L daily, as
   tolerated by BP.
   - Check [**Hospital1 **] lytes while aggressively diuresing
   - follow-up TTE
   - Cont lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would
   avoid stopping B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   .
   2. LLE ulcers and celllulitis: Plain films concerning for
   osteomyelitis. Given Vanco and Unasyn in ED. Vascular consulted and
   will consider debridement. Patient without leukocytosis or fever. Per
   vascular surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of his
   left LE.
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   3. Pulmonary opacity:
   Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA and with increased
   sputum production. This will be well covered with his current abx
   regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .
   4. CAD: S/p CABG [**10-5**]. Trop-T currently .23 -> .21 (baseline troponin
   .16-.23). MB negative. These labs make acute ischemia unlikely.
   Furthermore, no new ischemic changes noted on EKG.
   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol, and ACEI
   .
   5. Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   .
   6. COPD: Good O2 sats, mild wheezes on exam.
   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
   7. CKD: Creatinine 1.4 (baseline 1.5-2.5).
   - Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia:
   - Cont rosuvastatin
   .
   # DMII: Last HbA1C 5.8 ([**12-5**]).
   - Continue glargine and humalog ISS.  Titrate up as tolerated.
   .
   # Anemia: Hct 26, with baseline mid 20s.
   - Continue erythopoeitin
   - Daily hcts
   .
   # FEN:
   - Cardiac diabetic diet
   .
   # ACCESS: PIV
   .
   # PROPH: heparin SC, bowel reg
   .
   # DISPO: CCU pending diuresis with hemodynamic stability.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 82-year-old male with a history of CAD, systolic HF, and PVD, who presents with acute decompensated HF, LLE cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. The patient is currently receiving IV diuresis with lasix and metolazone, and has a goal of negative 3L daily fluid output. The patient is also receiving empiric antibiotics for possible osteomyelitis and pneumonia. The patient's cardiac status is being closely monitored, with a focus on controlling atrial fibrillation and maintaining adequate blood pressure. The patient's respiratory status is also being monitored, with a focus on managing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and pneumonia. The patient's kidney function is being closely monitored, with a focus on managing chronic kidney disease (CKD) and potential hyperkalemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of cardiac function: The patient's acute decompensated HF may worsen if the patient does not respond to diuresis and medication.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's LLE cellulitis may progress to osteomyelitis if not adequately treated with antibiotics and debridement.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen if not adequately treated with antibiotics and respiratory support.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's CKD and potential hyperkalemia may worsen if not adequately managed with medication and close monitoring.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not adequately managed with erythropoietin and daily hct.
6. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's DMII may worsen if not adequately managed with medication and close monitoring.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not adequately managed with medication and close monitoring.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and pneumonia may worsen if not adequately managed with respiratory support and oxygen therapy.
9. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if not adequately managed with medication and close monitoring.
10. Sepsis: The patient's infection may worsen if not adequately treated with antibiotics and close monitoring.

Summary:

The patient is a 82-year-old male with a history of CAD, systolic HF, and PVD, who presents with acute decompensated HF, LLE cellulitis, and infection of the wound in his distal forefoot. He is currently in the ICU and is being treated with IV diuresis, antibiotics, and anticoagulation therapy. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 94/33 mmHg. He has bilateral edema and is on oxygen therapy. His laboratory results show elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels, as well as decreased platelet count.

Potential medical complications:

1. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may indicate acute kidney injury. This could worsen his overall condition and increase his risk of complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient has cellulitis and infection of his wound, which could lead to sepsis. This is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and treatment.
3. Pulmonary edema: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he has bilateral edema and is at risk for developing pulmonary edema. This could worsen his respiratory function and increase his risk of complications.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias. This could worsen his cardiac function and increase his risk of complications.
5. Wound infection: The patient's wound is infected, which could lead to further complications if not properly treated. This could include the development of osteomyelitis or sepsis.
6. Pneumonia: The patient has a retrocardiac opacity on his chest X-ray, which could indicate pneumonia. This is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and treatment.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, which could worsen his cardiac function and increase his risk of complications.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose level is low, which could worsen his overall condition and increase his risk of complications.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for developing complications, particularly sepsis, acute kidney injury, and cardiac arrhythmias. It is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and treat these complications promptly.

   .
   1. Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%: Patient continues to be
   overloaded and has been diuresing well on lasix drip with metolazone.
   Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies include Na intake,
   hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular dysfunction. Had similar
   episode in [**12-6**], which responded well to IV diuresis.
   - Continue lasix gtt with PO metolazone.  Goal negative 3L daily, as
   tolerated by BP.
   - Check [**Hospital1 **] lytes while aggressively diuresing
   - follow-up TTE
   - Cont lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would
   avoid stopping B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   .
   2. LLE ulcers and celllulitis: Plain films concerning for
   osteomyelitis. Given Vanco and Unasyn in ED. Vascular consulted and
   will consider debridement. Patient without leukocytosis or fever. Per
   vascular surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of his
   left LE.
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   3. Pulmonary opacity:

   sputum production. This will be well covered with his current abx
   regimen.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, systolic heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease, who presents with acute decompensated heart failure, left lower extremity cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. He has been diagnosed with acute on chronic systolic heart failure, with an estimated ejection fraction of 20-30%. He is receiving diuretic therapy with furosemide and metolazone, and his blood pressure is being closely monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin T levels, indicating possible cardiac ischemia, but the electrocardiogram (EKG) does not show any new ischemic changes. His white blood cell count is normal, and his blood cultures are pending. He has been prescribed antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, for the treatment of his cellulitis and potential osteomyelitis.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 98% on nasal cannula oxygen. His physical examination reveals bilateral edema in his legs, with a well-wrapped dressing on his left foot. He has bibasilar crackles on his lung examination.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's heart failure is likely to worsen if his blood pressure is not controlled, and if his diuretic therapy is not effective.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's wound in the distal forefoot may become infected with osteomyelitis, which could lead to further complications.
3. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of peripheral vascular disease and immobility make him at risk for pulmonary embolism.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he may develop respiratory failure if his oxygenation is not maintained.
5. Sepsis: The patient's infection may lead to sepsis, which could be life-threatening.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and cardiac ischemia make him at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his kidney function may worsen if his blood pressure is not controlled.
8. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and he may develop anemia if his blood loss is not managed.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is elevated, and he may develop hyperglycemia if his diabetes is not managed.
10. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and edema make him at risk for pressure ulcers.

   function, new WMA.

   avoid stopping B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   .
   # LLE ulcers and celllulitis: Plain films concerning for osteomyelitis.
   Given Vanco and Unasyn in ED. Vascular consulted and will consider
   debridement. Patient without leukocytosis or fever. Per vascular
   surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of his left LE.
   - Follow up vascular recs. [**Month (only) 60**] need foot MRI for further eval for

   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CAD, systolic HF, and PVD, who presents with acute decompensated HF, LLE cellulitis, and infection of the wound in his distal forefoot. He has been experiencing volume overload, with a positive heart failure review of systems (ROS) and elevated BNP levels. He has had difficulty with diuresis in the past, requiring CVVH and milrinone. The patient is currently receiving IV lasix boluses and lasix gtt, and is being aggressively diuresed to achieve a goal of negative 2-3L daily, as tolerated by BP.

The patient's LLE ulcers and cellulitis are concerning for osteomyelitis, and he has been started on empiric vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. Vascular consultation has been requested, and the patient may require debridement. He also has a pulmonary opacity on CXR, which is concerning for PNA, but his current antibiotic regimen covers this.

The patient's CAD is stable, with no new ischemic changes noted on EKG. He has atrial fibrillation, which is well-controlled, and is not on warfarin anticoagulation. He also has COPD, CKD, hypercholesterolemia, DMII, anemia, and FEN.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening HF: The patient's HF is currently decompensated, and may worsen if not properly managed.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's LLE ulcers and cellulitis are concerning for osteomyelitis, which could lead to further complications and potentially life-threatening infections.
3. PNA: The patient's pulmonary opacity on CXR is concerning for PNA, which could lead to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Ischemia: Although the patient's CAD is stable, he may still be at risk for ischemia, particularly if his HF worsens or if he develops new ischemic changes on EKG.
5. Bleeding: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy for his atrial fibrillation, which increases his risk of bleeding complications.
6. Infection: The patient's cellulitis and wound infection increase his risk of developing further infections, particularly if his immune system is compromised.
7. Renal failure: The patient's CKD and diuretic therapy increase his risk of developing renal failure, particularly if his creatinine levels continue to rise.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to experience blood loss or if his erythropoietin levels are not adequately managed.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, systolic heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease, who presents with acute decompensated heart failure, left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. He has been diuresing well on lasix drip with metolazone and has been prescribed antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient's condition is critical due to acute on chronic systolic heart failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Heart Failure: The patient's heart failure is acute on chronic, and his ejection fraction is 20-30%. If not managed properly, his condition could deteriorate, leading to further fluid accumulation, hypotension, and even cardiogenic shock.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's LLE ulcers and cellulitis are concerning for osteomyelitis, which could lead to sepsis, septic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's retrocardiac opacity on CXR is concerning for pneumonia, which could lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and even death.
4. Ischemia: Although the patient's troponin levels are trending down, there is still a risk of ischemia, particularly given his history of coronary artery disease and recent cardiac surgery.
5. Bleeding Complications: The patient is on anticoagulation therapy with heparin, which increases the risk of bleeding complications, particularly in the setting of gastrointestinal bleeding or surgical interventions.
6. Infection: The patient's wounds and IV lines pose a risk of infection, which could lead to sepsis, septic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Renal Insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level is 1.4, which could worsen with further fluid accumulation, diuretic therapy, or nephrotoxic medications.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's diabetes management is complex, and there is a risk of hypoglycemia, particularly with the use of insulin and sulfonylureas.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic kidney disease and may worsen with further blood loss or bleeding complications.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk of developing various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are essential to prevent or mitigate these complications and improve his overall outcome.

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   [**2129-3-7**]
   - Family meeting held with palliative care ([**Doctor Last Name 8368**]). Per discussion, no
   longer wants hospice at home.
   - Diuresed with UOP 150-200cc per hour on lasix gtt at 12.5-20.
   - Continued Vanc/Zosyn
   - Vascular:Cont Abx (? will need PICC line now); ACE wraps to LE BL.
   Multipodus boot to RLE. POssible debridement of wound; Adaptic to leg
   ulcers. Wet to dry on distal wound
   .
   TTE The left and right atrium are moderately dilated. Left ventricular
   wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is mildly
   dilated. There is severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction
   with inferior and inferolateral thinning/akinesis and hypokinesis of
   the anterior septum and anterior wall. The apex and remaining segments

   Assessment and Plan
   82 yo male with a hx of CAD s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD presents
   with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection of wound
   in distal forefoot.
   1. Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%:
   Patient continues to be overloaded and has been diuresing well on lasix
   drip with metolazone. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies
   include Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular
   dysfunction.
   - Continue lasix gtt with PO metolazone.  Goal negative 2L as tolerated
   by BP.
   - Check [**Hospital1 **] lytes while aggressively diuresing- Cont lisinopril and
   carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would avoid stopping
   B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   - consider starting spironolactone given his severe CHF
   2. Hypotension
   Etiology of his relatively low blood pressures this morning is likely
   related to RV dysfunction, systolic dysfunction, and aggressive
   diuresis.
   - continue diuresis and monitor BP closely
   3. LLE ulcers and celllulitis:
   Per vascular surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of
   his left LE.
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   4. Pulmonary opacity:
   Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA and with increased
   sputum production. This will be well covered with his current abx
   regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .
   5. CAD: S/p CABG [**10-5**]. Trop-T currently .23 -> .21 (baseline troponin
   .16-.23). MB negative. These labs make acute ischemia unlikely.
   Furthermore, no new ischemic changes noted on EKG.
   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol, and ACEI
   .
   5. Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   - will follow-up with PCP regarding need for anticoagulation
   .
   6. COPD: Good O2 sats, mild wheezes on exam.
   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
   7. CKD:   (baseline 1.5-2.5).
   - Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output
   .
   8. Hypercholesterolemia:
   - Cont rosuvastatin
   .
   9. DMII: Last HbA1C 5.8 ([**12-5**]).
   - Continue glargine and humalog ISS.  Titrate up as tolerated.
   .
   10. Anemia: Hct 26, with baseline mid 20s.
   - Continue erythopoeitin
   - Daily hcts
   .
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD, presenting with acute decompensated HF, LLE cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. The patient has been diagnosed with symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with cavity dilation and extensive regional systolic dysfunction, consistent with multivessel CAD. The patient is currently on diuresis with lasix drip and metolazone, and is being treated with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of cardiac function: The patient's cardiac function is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to cardiac arrest or death.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot, which could spread to other parts of the body and lead to sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has mild wheezes on exam and is on oxygen therapy, which could lead to respiratory failure if not closely monitored.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a history of CKD and is currently on diuresis, which could lead to further decline in renal function.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient has a history of bleeding disorders and is on anticoagulation therapy, which could lead to hemorrhagic complications.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient is on diuresis and has a history of electrolyte imbalance, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Wound complications: The patient has a history of wound infection and cellulitis, which could lead to further complications such as sepsis, amputation, or death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue diuresis with lasix drip and metolazone to manage heart failure.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac function closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Continue empiric antibiotic therapy for infection and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust oxygen therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust diuretic therapy as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's wound status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Consider starting spironolactone for the patient's severe CHF.
9. Consider starting warfarin anticoagulation for the patient's atrial fibrillation.
10. Monitor the patient's blood sugar levels closely and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient, an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) status post coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), presents with acute decompensated heart failure (HF) with left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. He has been diuresing well on a lasix drip with metolazone and is being managed for acute on chronic systolic HF with an estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 20-30%.

The patient's cardiovascular status is complicated by atrial fibrillation (AF) with a controlled heart rate, mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. He has also been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and hypercholesterolemia.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with good oxygen saturation and mild wheezes on examination. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is being treated with fluticasone-salmeterol.

The patient's neurological status is normal, with no evidence of acute neurological deficits. However, his peripheral vascular status is compromised, with bilateral edema and poor options for revascularization of his left lower extremity.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, with a hemoglobin (Hb) level of 8.4 g/dL, and moderate kidney dysfunction, with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL. His troponin T level is elevated at 0.23 ng/mL, indicating possible myocardial injury.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's EF is severely decreased, and he is being managed with diuretics and vasodilators. Further exacerbation of his heart failure could lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
2. Sepsis: The patient's LLE cellulitis and wound infection pose a risk of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's immobility and CKD increase his risk of developing pulmonary embolism, which could be fatal if not recognized and treated promptly.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's CKD and diuretic therapy increase his risk of developing acute kidney injury, which could further compromise his renal function.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's AF and mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension increase his risk of cardiovascular instability, which could lead to cardiac arrest or death.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and possible pneumonia increase his risk of respiratory failure, which could lead to intubation and mechanical ventilation.
7. Infection: The patient's wound infection and possible osteomyelitis increase his risk of developing further infections, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor his condition and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent adverse outcomes.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a history of multivessel coronary artery disease (CAD), who has been admitted to the ICU. The patient's condition has deteriorated, with evidence of symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy, cavity dilation, and extensive regional systolic dysfunction, consistent with multivessel CAD. The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is severely depressed at 25%.

The patient's cardiac condition is further complicated by moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, moderate tricuspid regurgitation, and mildly dilated ascending aorta. The patient's echocardiogram shows no pericardial effusion.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated levels of troponin-T, CK, and CKMB, consistent with myocardial infarction or ischemia. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows tachycardia, hypertension, and hypotension, indicating instability.

The patient's respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen therapy, with an SpO2 of 96%. The patient's ABG results indicate a respiratory acidosis.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their critical condition, but they are unable to assess the patient's peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, and other vital signs.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation, which can further compromise cardiac function.
2. Cardiac failure, which can lead to pulmonary edema, hypoxia, and respiratory failure.
3. Myocardial infarction or ischemia, which can further compromise cardiac function and increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Sepsis or septic shock, which can arise from the patient's underlying infections or invasive lines.
5. Respiratory failure, which can arise from the patient's underlying lung disease or cardiac failure.
6. Renal failure, which can arise from the patient's underlying kidney disease or hypovolemia.
7. Neurologic complications, such as stroke or seizures, which can arise from the patient's underlying cardiac condition or hypoxia.

Based on this information, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and provide aggressive management of their cardiac, respiratory, and hemodynamic instability.

   Assessment and Plan
   82 yo male with a hx of CAD s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD presents
   with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection of wound
   in distal forefoot.
   1. Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%:
   Patient continues to be overloaded and has been diuresing well on lasix
   drip with metolazone. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies
   include Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular
   dysfunction.
   - Continue lasix gtt with PO metolazone.  Goal negative 2L as tolerated
   by BP.
   - Check [**Hospital1 **] lytes while aggressively diuresing- Cont lisinopril and
   carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would avoid stopping
   B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   - consider starting spironolactone given his severe CHF
   2. Hypotension
   Etiology of his relatively low blood pressures this morning is likely
   related to RV dysfunction, systolic dysfunction, and aggressive
   diuresis.
   - continue diuresis and monitor BP closely
   3. LLE ulcers and celllulitis:
   Per vascular surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of
   his left LE.
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   4. Pulmonary opacity:
   Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA and with increased
   sputum production. This will be well covered with his current abx
   regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .
   5. CAD: S/p CABG [**10-5**]. Trop-T currently .23 -> .21 (baseline troponin
   .16-.23). MB negative. These labs make acute ischemia unlikely.
   Furthermore, no new ischemic changes noted on EKG.
   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol, and ACEI
   .
   5. Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   - will follow-up with PCP regarding need for anticoagulation
   .
   6. COPD: Good O2 sats, mild wheezes on exam.
   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
   7. CKD:   (baseline 1.5-2.5).
   - Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output
   .
   8. Hypercholesterolemia:
   - Cont rosuvastatin
   .
   9. DMII: Last HbA1C 5.8 ([**12-5**]).
   - Continue glargine and humalog ISS.  Titrate up as tolerated.
   .
   10. Anemia: Hct 26, with baseline mid 20s.
   - Continue erythopoeitin
   - Daily hcts
   .
   .

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD, who presents with acute decompensated HF, LLE cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot.
* The patient has a low ejection fraction (EF 20-30%), and his systolic function is depressed.
* He is experiencing hypotension, likely due to RV dysfunction, systolic dysfunction, and aggressive diuresis.
* The patient has bilateral leg edema, and his left leg has ulcers and cellulitis.
* He has a pulmonary opacity on CXR, which is concerning for PNA, and is being treated with antibiotics.
* The patient has a history of CAD, and his troponin levels are elevated, but acute ischemia is unlikely.
* He has atrial fibrillation, which is well-controlled, and is not on warfarin anticoagulation.
* The patient has COPD, CKD, hypercholesterolemia, DMII, and anemia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Worsening of systolic HF and cardiac function, potentially leading to cardiac arrest or death.
* Development of pulmonary edema or respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying COPD and cardiac condition.
* Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's low platelet count and the use of anticoagulants.
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's infected wound and cellulitis.
* Potential need for surgical intervention to debride the wound and restore blood flow to the affected limb.
* Risk of kidney injury or acute kidney injury due to the patient's underlying CKD and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
* Potential need for mechanical ventilation or non-invasive positive pressure ventilation due to the patient's respiratory compromise.
* Risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation, due to the patient's underlying cardiac condition and the use of medications.

**Plan:**

* Continue lasix drip with metolazone to manage the patient's fluid overload.
* Monitor the patient's blood pressure and electrolyte levels closely.
* Continue antibiotics for the patient's infected wound and cellulitis.
* Consider starting spironolactone to treat the patient's severe CHF.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust medications as necessary.
* Consider starting mechanical ventilation or non-invasive positive pressure ventilation if the patient's respiratory compromise worsens.
* Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust medications as necessary to prevent kidney injury or acute kidney injury.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic heart failure (HF), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute decompensated HF, left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 82 beats per minute, blood pressure of 95/40 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.8 K/μL, hemoglobin of 8.4 g/dL, platelet count of 362 K/μL, creatinine of 1.4 mg/dL, and troponin-T of 0.23 ng/mL.

The patient's medical conditions include acute on chronic systolic HF with an estimated ejection fraction of 20-30%, LLE ulcers and cellulitis, pulmonary opacity, CAD, atrial fibrillation, COPD, CKD, hypercholesterolemia, DMII, anemia, and FEN.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue lasix drip with PO metolazone to achieve a goal of negative 3L daily urine output.
2. Check hospital lab values while aggressively diuresing and follow up with a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE).
3. Continue empiric vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam antibiotics.
4. Monitor temperature, white blood cell count, and sputum production.
5. Continue carvedilol and ASA for CAD.
6. Monitor atrial fibrillation rhythm on telemetry.
7. Continue fluticasone-salmeterol for COPD.
8. Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output.
9. Continue rosuvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.
10. Continue glargine and humalog ISS for DMII.
11. Continue erythropoietin and daily hemoglobin checks for anemia.
12. Provide cardiac diabetic diet and continue heparin sodium and bowel regimen for prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

1. Worsening heart failure with increased risk of cardiac arrest and death.
2. Development of sepsis and septic shock from untreated cellulitis and infection.
3. Increased risk of stroke and transient ischemic attack (TIA) due to atrial fibrillation.
4. Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) from COPD and pulmonary opacity.
5. Kidney injury and acute kidney injury (AKI) due to diuresis and CKD.
6. Hyperglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) from DMII.
7. Anemia and bleeding due to anemia and anticoagulation therapy.
8. Infection and sepsis from untreated wounds and cellulitis.
9. Cardiac arrhythmias and ventricular tachycardia (VT) from CAD and atrial fibrillation.
10. Increased risk of falls and pressure ulcers due to immobility and poor nutrition.

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medical conditions closely to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, systolic heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease who presented with acute decompensated heart failure, left lower extremity cellulitis, and infection of a wound in the distal forefoot. He has been diuresed with Lasix and has shown some improvement. However, he remains hypotensive, and his left lower extremity ulcers and cellulitis are being managed with empiric antibiotics and wound care. He also has atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic kidney disease, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's left lower extremity cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot may progress to sepsis if not managed promptly and effectively.
2. Heart Failure: The patient's acute decompensated heart failure may worsen if not managed aggressively with diuresis and other medications.
3. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's atrial fibrillation and recent bilateral spontaneous psoas hematomas may increase his risk of pulmonary embolism.
4. Wound Complications: The patient's left lower extremity ulcers and cellulitis may lead to wound complications such as abscesses, gangrene, or amputation.
5. Infection: The patient's wound infection may spread to other parts of the body, leading to systemic infection and sepsis.
6. Kidney Injury: The patient's chronic kidney disease and recent diuresis may increase his risk of kidney injury or worsening of kidney function.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and recent bilateral spontaneous psoas hematomas may increase his risk of respiratory failure.
8. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation and recent bilateral spontaneous psoas hematomas may increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
9. Stroke: The patient's atrial fibrillation and recent bilateral spontaneous psoas hematomas may increase his risk of stroke.
10. Death: The patient's complex medical conditions and recent bilateral spontaneous psoas hematomas may increase his risk of death.

   Assessment and Plan
   82 yo male with a hx of CAD s/p CABG, systolic HF, and PVD presents
   with acute decompensated HF with LLE cellulitis and infection of wound
   in distal forefoot.
   1. Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%:
   Patient continues to be overloaded and has been diuresing well on lasix
   drip with metolazone. Unclear precipitant, but possible etiologies
   include Na intake, hypertension, ischemia, or worsening valvular
   dysfunction.
   - Continue lasix gtt with PO metolazone.  Goal negative 2L as tolerated
   by BP.
   - Check [**Hospital1 **] lytes while aggressively diuresing- Cont lisinopril and
   carvedilol with careful observation of BPs. Would avoid stopping
   B-blocker abruptly to prevent catecholamine rebound.
   - consider starting spironolactone given his severe CHF
   2. Hypotension
   Etiology of his relatively low blood pressures this morning is likely
   related to RV dysfunction, systolic dysfunction, and aggressive
   diuresis.
   - continue diuresis and monitor BP closely
   3. LLE ulcers and celllulitis:
   Per vascular surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of
   his left LE.
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   4. Pulmonary opacity:
   Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA and with increased
   sputum production. This will be well covered with his current abx
   regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .
   5. CAD: S/p CABG [**10-5**]. Trop-T currently .23 -> .21 (baseline troponin
   .16-.23). MB negative. These labs make acute ischemia unlikely.
   Furthermore, no new ischemic changes noted on EKG.
   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol, and ACEI
   .
   5. Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   - will follow-up with PCP regarding need for anticoagulation
   .
   6. COPD: Good O2 sats, mild wheezes on exam.
   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
   7. CKD:   (baseline 1.5-2.5).
   - Trend creatinine given diuresis and monitor urine output
   .
   8. Hypercholesterolemia:
   - Cont rosuvastatin
   .
   9. DMII: Last HbA1C 5.8 ([**12-5**]).
   - Continue glargine and humalog ISS.  Titrate up as tolerated.
   .
   10. Anemia: Hct 26, with baseline mid 20s.
   - Continue erythopoeitin

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, systolic heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease, who presented with acute decompensated heart failure, left lower extremity cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. He has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, and is being treated with furosemide, metolazone, and other medications. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, blood pressure of 100/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. He has a positive fluid balance, with a total fluid input of 1,589 mL and a total fluid output of 2,904 mL. His laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin level, and creatinine level.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Heart Failure: The patient's acute decompensated heart failure may worsen if he does not continue to diuresis and if his medication regimen is not optimized.
2. Sepsis: The patient's cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot may lead to sepsis if not properly treated.
3. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's atrial fibrillation and immobilization may increase his risk of developing a pulmonary embolism.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory failure may worsen if he does not receive adequate oxygen therapy and if his respiratory status is not closely monitored.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease (CKD) and diuresis may lead to renal failure if his creatinine level continues to rise and if his urine output does not improve.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's diabetes mellitus type II (DMII) and glycosuria may lead to hyperglycemia if his blood glucose levels are not closely monitored and if his insulin regimen is not optimized.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if his hemoglobin level continues to decline and if his erythropoietin levels are not adequate.
8. Infection: The patient's wound infection and cellulitis may lead to a systemic infection if not properly treated.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if his platelet count continues to decline and if his medication regimen is not optimized.
10. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and heart failure may lead to cardiovascular complications such as myocardial infarction, stroke, or cardiac arrest if not properly managed.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic heart failure (HF), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He presented with acute decompensated HF, left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis, and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot. The patient is currently receiving diuretic therapy with Lasix and metolazone, and his blood pressure is being closely monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's LLE cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and pulmonary opacity on CXR increase the risk of respiratory failure, which can be exacerbated by the patient's HF and diuresis.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of CAD and systolic HF increase the risk of cardiac arrest, particularly in the setting of acute decompensated HF and hypotension.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease (CKD) and diuresis increase the risk of renal failure, which can be exacerbated by the patient's HF and medications.
5. Wound Complications: The patient's LLE cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot increase the risk of wound complications, such as osteomyelitis and amputation.
6. Bleeding Complications: The patient's history of bilateral spontaneous psoas hematomas and his current use of anticoagulation therapy increase the risk of bleeding complications, particularly in the setting of invasive procedures.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's diuresis and use of medications such as Lasix and metolazone increase the risk of electrolyte imbalance, particularly hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.
8. Infection: The patient's LLE cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot increase the risk of infection, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression and invasive procedures.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He presents with acute decompensated heart failure with left lower extremity (LLE) cellulitis and infection of the wound in the distal forefoot.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 36.6°C (97.8°F), heart rate 85 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure 104/54 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 93%.
* Physical examination: General condition is normal, with disorientation. HEENT is normal, with dry mucous membranes. Cardiovascular examination reveals irregular heartbeat with no murmurs or gallop. Pulmonary examination shows clear lungs with distant breath sounds. Abdominal examination reveals soft, non-tender abdomen with distension. Extremities show 2+ bilateral lower extremity edema with bilateral feet in multipodous boots, with left foot well-wrapped with no evidence of bleeding or drainage through dressing, and less erythema on the left lower extremity.
* Laboratory results: Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL, hematocrit 26.7%, platelet count 396,000/μL, creatinine 1.6 mg/dL, and troponin-T 0.23 ng/mL.

The patient's current medications include:

* Lasix (furosemide) 20mg IV every 4 hours
* Metolazone 10mg IV every 24 hours
* Lisinopril 10mg PO every 24 hours
* Carvedilol 6.25mg PO every 12 hours
* Aspirin 81mg PO every 24 hours
* Rosuvastatin 10mg PO every 24 hours
* Fluticasone-salmeterol 2 inhalations every 12 hours
* Glargine insulin 10 units subcutaneously every 12 hours
* Humalog insulin 5 units subcutaneously every 12 hours
* Erythropoietin 10,000 units subcutaneously every 24 hours
* Vitamin K 10mg IV every 24 hours

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Acute on chronic systolic heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen due to the decompensation, and the patient may require more aggressive diuresis and vasodilation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and the patient may require more aggressive vasopressor therapy to maintain adequate blood pressure.
3. Left lower extremity ulcers and cellulitis: The patient's left lower extremity ulcers and cellulitis may worsen, and the patient may require more aggressive wound care and antibiotic therapy.
4. Pulmonary opacity: The patient's pulmonary opacity may worsen, and the patient may require more aggressive respiratory therapy and antibiotic therapy.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, and the patient may require more aggressive anti-arrhythmic therapy.
6. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen due to the diuresis and vasodilation, and the patient may require more aggressive fluid management and electrolyte monitoring.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to the chronic kidney disease, and the patient may require more aggressive erythropoietin therapy.

In conclusion, the patient's current condition is complex, and the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent potential medical complications.

   of wound in distal forefoot.
   1. Acute on chronic systolic HF, EF 20-30%:
   Diruesing well on lasix gtt.

   - Cont lisinopril and carvedilol with careful observation of BPs.

   rebound.

   - consider starting spironolactone given his severe CHF

   dysfunction.
   - continue diuresis and monitor BP closely
   3. LLE ulcers and celllulitis:
   Per vascular surgery, patient has poor options for revascularation of
   his left LE.
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - F/u blood cultures
   - Continue empiric vanco and pip-tazo x 7 days
   - Wet-to-dry dressing on toe, adaptic on bullae
   .
   4. Pulmonary opacity:
   Retrocardiac opacity on CXR concerning for PNA and with increased
   sputum production. This will be well covered with his current abx
   regimen.
   - Cont abx as above
   - F/u blood cx
   - Send sputum cx if cough becomes productive
   - Monitor temp, WBC count
   .

   - Cont ASA, rosuvastatin, carvedilol, and ACEI
   .
   5. Atrial Fibrillation: Rate currently well controlled. Patient not on
   warfarin anticoagulation.
   - Cont carvedilol and ASA.
   - Monitor rhythm on telemetry.
   - will follow-up with PCP regarding need for anticoagulation
   .

   - Cont fluticasone-salmeterol
   .
